Terms: What is the significance of categorizing ethernet cables?
Definitions: The categories define the maximum speed the cables can have without having any cross talk/interference

Terms: What do the numbers of the CAT3-7 cable categories represent?
Definitions: The number represents the tightness of the twists that are applied to the wires

Terms: WHat is the speed of a CAT 3 wire?
Definitions: 10Mbps

Terms: WHat is the speed of a CAT 5 wire?
Definitions: 100Mbps

Terms: What is the speed of a CAT 5e wire and what does the e stand for??
Definitions: 1Gbps. enhanced

Terms: What is the speed of a CAT 6 wire?
Definitions: 1Gbps or 10 Gbps for a cable under 100 meters.

Terms: What is the speed of a CAT 6a? What does the a stand for?
Definitions: 10Gbps, augmented

Terms: What is the speed of a CAT 7 wire?
Definitions: 10Gbps and added shielding to the wires.

Terms: How do Fiber Optic cables send data?
Definitions: By using pulses of light to send data.

Terms: What are the two types of tips on Fiber Optic cables?
Definitions: UPC and APC

Terms: What describes serial cable transmission types?
Definitions: Transmits one bit at a time, more common than parallel, faster transmission rates.

Terms: What are common serial standard devices?
Definitions: USB, SATA

Terms: What describes parallel cable transmission types?
Definitions: Transmits multiple bits simultaneously, electrical signal interference, smaller transmission distance than serial

Terms: What are the DHH cables?
Definitions: IDE(also called PATA), SCSI, SATA. Sata uses serial transmission rates while IDE and SCSI use parallel.

Terms: What does VGA stand for? How is the data transmitted?
Definitions: Video Graphics Array. It is analog and only transmits video.

Terms: DVI-D, DVI-I, DVI-A
Definitions: Digital, Analogue, or Integrated. Video only

Terms: DisplayPost
Definitions: Can be copper of fiber. 3 to 15m

Terms: What does HDMI stand for
Definitions: High-Definition Multimedia Interface. It is digital and transfers video and audio.

Terms: What is the color order of 568A wiring standard?
Definitions: GW, G, OW, B, BW, O, BW, B.

Terms: What is the color order of the 568b wiring standard?
Definitions: OW, O, GW, B, BW, G, BW, B

Terms: What is the most common network connector that is used in networking?
Definitions: RJ45

Terms: How many pins is the RJ45 modular connector?
Definitions: 8 pin connector. Uses 8 UTP cables.

Terms: What is RJ45 used to connect?
Definitions: Used to connect computers and network devices in a LAN

Terms: What is the difference between RJ45 and RJ48?
Definitions: RJ48 uses STP cable.

Terms: What is the main purpose of a RJ11 connector?
Definitions: (4 wire) Connector used to connect telephone equipment. Also, connects computers to a network through the computers modem

Terms: How many pins are used on the RJ11?
Definitions: 4 pins

Terms: What is the BNC connector?
Definitions: It is an RF connector used on coaxial cable.

Terms: What type of media is the BNC connector used for?
Definitions: Analog and digital transmissions as well as audio.

Terms: What is the F-type connector?
Definitions: Threaded connector typically used on coaxial cables

Terms: Where will you most likely see a F-type cable?
Definitions: Primarily used by cable providers to attach cable modems. Also used with satellite internet

Terms: In a UPC connection, how is the light reflected?
Definitions: The light is reflected back to the light source. Because of this, some signal loss may occur.

Terms: IN a APC connections, how is the light reflected?
Definitions: Light is reflected at an angle into the wall of the cable and greatly reduces the signal loss of UPC

Terms: In which ports can a joystick plug into?
Definitions: USB and DA-15 port.

Terms: What type of cable is the BNC connector used with?
Definitions: Coaxial cables

Terms: What type of cable is the BNC connector used with?
Definitions: Coaxial cables

Terms: Can a DVI cable be converted into an HDMI?
Definitions: yes

Terms: Can a DVI cable be converted into a VGA?
Definitions: yes

Terms: Name the two cable type a USB can be converted to.
Definitions: Ethernet, serial

Terms: What cable type can a Molex be converted to?
Definitions: SATA

Terms: What is a main difference between VGA and DVI cables?
Definitions: VGA transfers data through analogue signals while DVI uses both.

Terms: What is a main difference between VGA and DVI cables?
Definitions: VGA transfers data through analogue signals while DVI uses both.

Terms: How many devices does a USB port support?
What is a sound card?
Definitions: Provides sound capabilities to the computer. Usually includes audio input/output ports and a MIDI device port.

Terms: What is a video card?
Definitions: Provides video capabilities to the computer- usually includes multiple video connections.

Terms: What is a network card?
Definitions: Provides network capabilities. Usually includes one network port.

Terms: What is a USB card?
Definitions: Provides USB communication capabilities to the computer. Includes multiple USB ports.

Terms: What is a FireWire card?
Definitions: Provides FireWire communication capabilities to the computer. Includes multiple ports

Terms: What is a storage card?
Definitions: Provides storage capabilities to a computer. Includes multiple storage ports.

Terms: What is a modem card?
Definitions: Provides dial-up capabilities and includes two RJ-11 ports, one for input and one for output.

Terms: What is a TV tuner card?
Definitions: Allows computer to display TV signals.

Terms: What is a video capture card?
Definitions: Allows the computer to display and capture video signals from a video to recording device.

Terms: What is a riser card?
Definitions: Provides ability to connect other cards to a slim fit computer. Referred to as a daughter board. Provides extra slots for expansion cards.

Terms: What is a thunderbolt card?
Definitions: Provides external connections of Apple products. Can support up to 7 devices.

Terms: What is throttling?
Definitions: Used to adjust the CPU speed. Used to reduce the operating frequency of the CPU during idle times.

Terms: What is cache memory?
Definitions: A type of RAM located closer to a processor and allows the processor to execute instructions to read and write data at a higher speed than the regular RAM. Often implemented with SRAM.

Terms: Which expansion slot uses a serial connection?
Definitions: PCIe. The serial connection uses two lanes. One to transmit and one to receive, full duplex.

Terms: What does hyperthreading allow?
Definitions: It allows a single processor to handle two independent sets of instructions at the same time.

Terms: What is dual core technology?
Definitions: A dual core processor contains two processor cores in a single processor package.

Terms: What is the difference between HT and dual core technology?
Definitions: Hyper threading only simulates two processors in a singly physical unit while dual core processors physically contain two processor cores in a single package.

Terms: What is Peltier cooling?
Definitions: A Peltier device gets colder when voltage is applied. A thermoelectric heat pump.

Terms: List the convective cooling methods.
Definitions: Heat sinks, Thermal paste, Cooling fins, cooling fans, heat pipes, water pumps, liquid cooling.

Terms: What CPU would be supported with a LGA 1155 CPU socket?
Definitions: Corei3/if/i7, Pentium, Celeron, Xeon.

Terms: What CPUs would be supported with an LGA 775 socket?
Definitions: Pentium 4, Celeron, Pentium 4 extreme edition, Core 2, Xeon.

Terms: On which components can you enable overclocking?
Definitions: RAM, Processor, System Bus.

Terms: What is a component that is always located on the CPU and accelerates the processing of instructions?
Definitions: L1 cache (not to be confused with L2 which can also appear on the motherboard.

Terms: What kind of memory do the L1 and L2 cache use?
Definitions: They both use SRAM

Terms: During a POST check, what will stop a computer from loading the OS system?
Definitions: CPU, memory, or video card failures.

Terms: What is the primary function of an integrated GPU(Graphics Processing Unit)
Definitions: To process video and graphics.

Terms: What are the standard AMD processor socket types?
Definitions: FM1, AM3

Terms: Which are the standard Intel processor socket types?
Definitions: LGA 775, LGA 1156, LGA 2011

Terms: What does PGA stand for?
Definitions: Pin Grid Area

Terms: What does LGA stand for?
Definitions: Land Grid Area

Terms: What is a sign of a failing CMOS battery?
Definitions: The computers internal clock is loses time at startup

Terms: What should you do when you want to enable hyper-threading, but when you check the BIOS settings, the HT options are dimmed?
Definitions: Update the processor. It is dimmed because the processor installed does not support HT technology.

Terms: What should you do when you want to enable hyper-threading, but the HT option is not available?
Definitions: Upgrade the BIOS. This is different than if the HT option is dimmed.

Terms: Windows computer issues errors about running out of virtual memory. How do you increase the amount of available virtual memory?
Definitions: Edit the size of the paging file in the OS.

Terms: How do you edit the size of the paging file in the OS?
Definitions: Click the settings button in the Performance section of the System Properties advance tab.

Terms: What are the usual 4 components beep codes point to?
Definitions: Memory, Video, Keyboard, or CPU.

Terms: A user reports overheating problem. What do you recommend as first step to solve it?
Definitions: Make sure the computer cover is closed and secured to maintain the correct airflow cooling circulation pattern through the computer.

Terms: A most likely cause of a computer overheating?
Definitions: Dust.

Terms: What is the maximum number of expansion slots an ATX motherboard can support?
Definitions: Max. 7 expansion slots

Terms: How many pins are in the ATX power connector?
Definitions: A 20-pin power connector

Terms: How many pins are used by the Micro-ATX, ITX, and Mini-ITX power connector?
Definitions: They use 20 or 24 pin connectors.

Terms: What is the southbridge responsible for?
Definitions: Manages I/O functions, system clock, drives and buses, APM and other devices.

Terms: How does the southbridge connect to the northbridge?
Definitions: It uses a PCI bus to communicate.

Terms: What does the northbridge control?
Definitions: It controls the system memory and AGP video ports, as well as could control cache memory. It is installed closer to the CPU than the southbridge. Communicates directly with the CPU using a 64-bit front side bus

Terms: What does the CMOS battery do?
Definitions: Provides power to the CMOS chip to enusre that CMOS settings are not lost when computer is turned off.

Terms: What is BIOS?
Definitions: Basic Input Output sequence. It is the first program executed when turning computer on.

Terms: What does the BIOS do when system is first booted?
Definitions: It identifies, tests, and initializes system devices-> such as: video display card, hard disk, system clock, CD-ROM drive, and more.

Terms: What is hyper-threading?
Definitions: A form of microprocessor parallelization where each physical processor is treated as two virtual processors. Makes on physical CPU appear as two logical CPUs.

Terms: What is overclocking?
Definitions: Increasing the clock rate of a computer to exceed that which is certified by the manufacturer. Increasing clock speed to boost processor performance.

Terms: What does UEFI stand for?
Definitions: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface

Terms: Which component supports communication between the CPU and RAM?
Definitions: The Northbridge- it also supports the PCI bus and AGP port.

Terms: What is the ATA interface responsible for?
Definitions: Connecting storage devices to the motherboard.

Terms: What is Bus mastering?
Definitions: The ability of a device to take control of a computers expansion bus and send data directly to another device on the bust without requiring the use of a CPU or its resources.

Terms: List the specifications for the standard PCI.
Definitions: 32 bit bus and up to 133 MBps bus speed.

Terms: List the specifications for the PCI 2.1 standard.
Definitions: 32 and 64 bit bus and up to 266 and 532 MBps.

Terms: List the general specifications for the PCIe standards.
Definitions: 32 bit bus- 2 to 16 GBps bus speeds.

Terms: List general the specifications for the PCIx standards.
Definitions: 64 bit bus and 1-9GBps.

Terms: What is SCSI?
Definitions: Small System Computer Interface.

Terms: What are the dimensions of an ATX form factor?
Definitions: 12 x 9.6 inches.

Terms: What are the dimensions of a micro-aTX form factor?
Definitions: 9.6x9.6 inches

Terms: What are the dimensions of mini-aTX form factor?
Definitions: 11.2x8.2 inches

Terms: What are the dimensions of an ITX form factor?
Definitions: 8.6x7.5 inches.

Terms: What are the dimensions of a mini-ITX form factor?
Definitions: 6.7x6.7 inches

Terms: What is a toner cartridge?
Definitions: Laser printer component-> a photo sensitive drum.

Terms: What is the photo sensitive drum?
Definitions: A component of the laser printer that holds a static charge. The laser writes to it.

Terms: Explain how the Laser printer works.
Definitions: Primary corona a uniform negative charge on the drum. Afterwards, a laser writes into the drum at a different charge where the data you want to print will be. The toner is then put onto the exposed image and sticks to the drum so the data is visible. Transfer corona puts charge on the paper. Toner is transferred to positively charged paper.

Terms: How to get the toner to stick to the paper? Seal the toner onto the paper?
Definitions: With heat and pressure from the Fuser Assembly.

Terms: List the seven steps of a laser printer.
Definitions: 1. processing- data is stored to the printer memory 2. Charging (primary corona) 3. Exposing (laser writes to drum and reduces charge) 4. Developing (toner hits drum). 5. Transfer (transfer corona- paper positive charge) 6. Fusing - (heat and pressure presses toner into paper) 7. Cleaning - (scrape off residual toner)

Terms: What does a color laser printer do differently?
Definitions: Instead of a transfer roller, there is a transfer belt that the colors are added to.

Terms: What component of the laser printer adds a uniform charge to the drum?
Definitions: Primary corona.

Terms: What component writes to the drum?
Definitions: The laser- by reducing the charge of the drum where data will appear.

Terms: What component makes the lasered words on the drum visible?
Definitions: The toner, by sticking to the charged path of the laser.

Terms: What component of a black and white laser printer charges the paper and allows the toner to transfer to the paper?
Definitions: The transfer corona/transfer roller

Terms: What to do if the photo sensitive drum wears out?
Definitions: Replace the drum

Terms: What was the first printer to introduce color printing?
Definitions: Inkjet printing

Terms: What printer uses ink cartridges?
Definitions: Inkjet

Terms: What computer puts a charge on the ink?
Definitions: Inkjet (not Laser which uses toner)

Terms: How does an Inkjet printer work?
Definitions: A print head houses the ink jets (CYMK). The print head rolls back and forth on a carriage, which allows the ink to shoot across the paper.

Terms: Where is the ink stored in an ink jet printer?
Definitions: In the ink cartridges

Terms: What are some components of the dot printer or impact printer?
Definitions: Print head, ink ribbon, pins that push through the print head.

Terms: For which device is a 6+2 pin power connection intended
Definitions: PCIe- it is an 8pin 12v power connection. PCIe can also use single 6 pin connectors for low-end power supply.

Terms: What is the Pin/voltage of a PCIe power connection?
Definitions: 8pin 12 volts.

Terms: What type of power connector does an ATA hard drive use?
Definitions: 4 pin that provides 5 or 12 volts.

Terms: What type of power connector does a SATA hard drive use?
Definitions: 15 pin that provides 3.3, 5, 0r 12 volts.

Terms: What is the max length a USB cable can reach?
Definitions: 5 meters

Terms: What do the 4 pins on a USB represent?
Definitions: 2 pins are for data and 2 pins are used for power.

Terms: What three types of hardware support hot swap capabilities?
Definitions: USB, IEEE 1394, eSATA

Terms: What is the max length a USB cable can reach?
Definitions: 5 meters

Terms: What do the 4 pins on a USB represent?
Definitions: 2 pins are for data and 2 pins are used for power.

Terms: What three types of hardware support hot swap capabilities?
Definitions: USB, IEEE 1394, eSATA

Terms: What factors affect drive thrashing?
Definitions: Memory, Paging file, Running processes, and Hard drives.

Terms: What is drive thrashing?
Definitions: When excessive amount of data is moved between RAM and paging file.

Terms: How many pins does Dual inline memory modules (DIMMS) have?
Definitions: 168 pins

Terms: How many pins does SODIMM have?
What does SODIMM stand for?
Definitions: Small Outline Dual Inline Memory Modules.

Terms: How many pins does SDR DIMM have versus DDR DIMM?
Definitions: SDR DIMM = 168 pins. DDR DIMM = 184 pins

Terms: How many pins do DDR1, DDR2, DDR3, and DDR4 have?
What does access speed refer to?
Definitions: Refers to the amount of time a memory module requires to provide data to a memory controller.

Terms: What is the interface between the physical memory and the CPU?
Definitions: The memory controller.

Terms: What happens if you add memory with faster speeds than the systems board minimum requirement?
Definitions: Acts normal. Using faster memory does not provide any performance benefit.

Terms: What happens if you add memory with slower speeds than the systems board minimum requirement?
Definitions: It will cause the CPU to waste time waiting for slower memory modules during I/O.

Terms: In what unit are access speeds measures?
Definitions: nanoseconds.

Terms: How many pins does SIMM have?
Definitions: 30 or 72 pins

Terms: What is a possible reason why ECC is not recognized after installing RAM with ECC?
Definitions: The motherboard does not support ECC memory. As a result, there is no error correcting, it is the same as non-ECC memory.

Terms: What kind of memory module can be installed in a laptop?
Definitions: SODIMMS and MicroDIMMS.

Terms: How many pins does SIMM have?
Definitions: 30 or 72 pins

Terms: What is a possible reason why ECC is not recognized after installing RAM with ECC?
Definitions: The motherboard does not support ECC memory. As a result, there is no error correcting, it is the same as non-ECC memory.

Terms: What kind of memory module can be installed in a laptop?
Definitions: SODIMMS and MicroDIMMS.
